description: From Old French via Middle English and Middle French entreprise, feminine past participle of entreprendre (“to undertake”), from entre (“in between”) + prendre (“to take”), from Latin inter + prehendō, see prehensile.

entries.meaning: A company, business, organization, or other purposeful endeavor.
examples: The government sponsored enterprises (GSEs) are a group of financial services corporations which have been created by the United States Congress.
A micro-enterprise is defined as a company or business having 5 or fewer employees and a low seed capital.

entries.meaning: An undertaking, venture, or project, especially a daring and courageous one.
examples: Biosphere 2 was a scientific enterprise aimed at the exploration of the complex web of interactions within life systems.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) A willingness to undertake new or risky projects; energy and initiative.
examples: He has shown great enterprise throughout his early career.

verbs.description: enterprise (third-person singular simple present enterprises, present participle enterprising, simple past and past participle enterprised)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To undertake an enterprise, or something hazardous or difficult.
(transitive) To undertake; to begin and attempt to perform; to venture upon.
examples: The business must be enterprised this night.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To treat with hospitality; to entertain.
